author: @neerajankam6196
text: Here's a shortcut to get to environment variables quicker.   1) Press Windows key and when the search bar shows up, type in 'env' 2) Click on 'Edit the system environment variables' and you'll directly be taken to the window where you can edit you env variables.

author: @josephturi
text: To do this in the command line and  set a global or system variable using SETX:: 1. Open command line as administrator 2. setx DB_USER "my_db_user" (> SUCCESS: Specified value was saved.) 3. Close and reopen command line 4. echo %DB_USER% my_db_user  setx DB_USER "my_db_user" will put it in the User Variables setx /m DB_USER "my_db_user"  will put it in the System Variables

author: @leustad
text: Hey Corey, all great but if you don't want to keep your environ variables permanent and want them to be active when ever the project is running;  have a look at this: https://github.com/kennethreitz/autoenv you can write your environ variables in the .env file and autoenv runs the .env file while activating your virtual environment.   Maybe wanna make a video about this not much known gem.
